Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a STORM System to Establish a Nanoscopy Laboratory at the City College of New York

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1337746
Sun

The PIs plan to acquire a 3-D multicolor N-STORM Superresolution Microscopy System and establish a
Nanoscopy Laboratory of the City College of New York (CCNY). The STORM system will immediately
enable 28 research topics or areas proposed by 21 faculty members, most of whom are leaders of their
own groups/labs, in 8 departments including Electrical Engineering, Biomedical Engineering, Physics,
Biology, Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering, Physiology/Pharmacology/Neuroscience, and Microbiology/
Immunology. The research activities enabled by N-STORM and performed in this project will
enhance the spatiotemporal resolution of STORM, clarify a number of biomedical hypotheses and
phenomena established by other means, and result in insightful novel biomedical knowledge. They will
promote teaching, training, and learning and improve basic science research, disease diagnostic
assessment, and therapeutics development. The results will be broadly disseminated and applied in the
fields of nanoscopy, cell biology, neurobiology, and medicine to enhance scientific, technological and
clinical understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With support of this NSF Major Research Instrument award a Nikon multicolor 3D Superresolution N-STORM microscope and an elite workstation were purchased and then the Nanoscopy Laboratory at the City College of New York (CCNY) was established. In addition to the existing confocal and TEM electrical microscope at CCNY the N-STORM system can provide superresolution fluorescence imaging to support advanced biological, physiological, and biomedical research for users at CCNY and other institutions in the tristate area. The Nanoscopy Laboratory can also provide students with opportunities in training and learning of sophisticated superresolution imaging instrument. By providing superresolution imaging and analysis the facilities have supported the research including algorithm development for data analysis of living cells, study of properties of parasite-derived immune-suppressive virus-like particles, elucidating endothelial glycocalyx structure and function, analysis of structures and immune-suppressive functions of proteins from a natural parasite of drosophila, emitter localization and motion tracking in nanoscopy imaging, and mitochondrial interactions with pre-synaptic architecture of motor neurons. The users of these researchers are inside as well as outside CCNY, including undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and faculty members. The Nanoscopy Laboratory will continue to be open to public users and support research and education by means of superresolution imaging and analysis.
